<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 377, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 903, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 177, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|> 0625/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> February/March 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 699, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 904, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the behaviour of a spring and use it to determine the mass of an object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 119, 489, 135]]<|/det|> A stand and spring have been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 150, 260, 166]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 686, 197]]<|/det|> Suspend a mass \(m = 100 \text{g}\) from the spring as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[337, 212, 643, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 453, 532, 470]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 484, 920, 501]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 515, 792, 532]]<|/det|>
Repeat this step for values of \(m = 200 \text{g}\) , \(m = 300 \text{g}\) , \(m = 400 \text{g}\) and \(m = 500 \text{g}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 546, 463, 562]]<|/det|>
Remove the mass \(m\) from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 811, 90]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of insulation on the cooling of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 260, 120]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 610, 151]]<|/det|> Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 166, 567, 182]]<|/det|> Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 196, 915, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 377, 532, 394]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 409, 146, 426]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 409, 529, 425]]<|/det|>
• Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 426, 500, 440]]<|/det|>
• Place the thermometer in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 441, 917, 471]]<|/det|>
• In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 472, 917, 502]]<|/det|>
• Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\) , \(t = 60 \text{s}\) , \(t = 90 \text{s}\) , \(t = 120 \text{s}\) , \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 502, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 509, 533]]<|/det|>
Remove the thermometer from the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 549, 148, 566]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 500, 565]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in (a) for beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 549, 920, 566]]<|/det|>
[2]

beaker A
with insulation		beaker B
without insulation
\(t/s\)\(\theta /\text {}^{\circ }\text {C}\)\(\theta /\text {}^{\circ }\text {C}\)
0
30

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 917, 107]]<|/det|>
Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 214, 918, 231]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 241, 148, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 287, 555, 319]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{90}}{T},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 330, 918, 363]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 377, 328, 393]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 453, 918, 471]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{1} = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 484, 180, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 484, 918, 517]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 528, 561, 560]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{90} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 571, 918, 604]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 619, 328, 635]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 696, 918, 714]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{2} = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 726, 146, 745]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 726, 918, 759]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t = 0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 772, 784, 790]]<|/det|>
Use your answers from (d)(i) and (d)(ii) to explain whether this is necessary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 866, 918, 884]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 119, 640, 136]]<|/det|>
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 150, 685, 167]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this additional experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[838, 210, 918, 228]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 243, 178, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 243, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 797, 88]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 470, 119]]<|/det|>
Use the separate ray-trace sheet provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 435, 135]]<|/det|>
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 145, 816, 621]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 636, 533, 653]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 667, 146, 686]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 667, 795, 683]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 683, 907, 714]]<|/det|>
Carefully draw round the block and label the corners \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) as indicated by Fig. 3.1. Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 730, 579, 746]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\) , 2 cm from \(\mathbf{A}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 761, 885, 777]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{EN}\) , as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8 cm long and at an angle \(\theta = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 777, 920, 795]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 616, 88]]<|/det|>
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 866, 135]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line EN, a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 149, 918, 197]]<|/det|>
View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block, from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 611, 212]]<|/det|>
Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 588, 243]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 258, 680, 273]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Extend this line to meet line \(\mathbf{CD}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 274, 918, 305]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\) . Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 320, 588, 335]]<|/det|>
Extend line EN to approximately 5cm below line CD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 336, 918, 367]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\) . Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{J}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 368, 918, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 146, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 399, 181, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 399, 640, 415]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{CD}\) and \(\mathbf{GF}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 415, 534, 430]]<|/det|>
An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 444, 918, 459]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) ............................................ $^\circ$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 475, 636, 491]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\beta\) between lines \(\mathbf{CD}\) and \(\mathbf{JH}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 505, 918, 520]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\beta =\) ............................................ $^\circ$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 521, 918, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 552, 685, 568]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 583, 918, 615]]<|/det|>
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results.

statement ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 660, 918, 675]]<|/det|>
justification ....................................................................................................................................

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 739, 148, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 739, 918, 755]]<|/det|>
Draw a new line EN, as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8cm long and at an angle \(\theta = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 770, 353, 785]]<|/det|>
Repeat the steps in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 785, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 846, 90]]<|/det|>
Describe one technique to use in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 144, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 273, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 305, 823, 337]]<|/det|>
<pre>Write your name, centre number and candidate number on your ray-trace sheet. <pre>Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 502, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 917, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables the student to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 141, 549, 170]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 180, 833, 197]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 211, 470, 227]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 242, 397, 258]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 273, 318, 288]]<|/det|>
· a selection of wires

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 289, 354, 304]]<|/det|>
· a variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 305, 260, 319]]<|/det|>
· an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 320, 260, 335]]<|/det|>
· a voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 351, 224, 367]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 381, 456, 397]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 412, 917, 445]]<|/det|>
· complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 459, 917, 492]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 506, 485, 522]]<|/det|>
